info.title: SUSE Best Practices Strategy and Plan
info.subtitle: Internal Only

sect1.title: Background
sect1.para: In many enterprises, a lot of hidden IT knowledge and experience exists. This is also the case for SUSE, no matter which product you are looking at. For every product or solution, there are subject matter experts that have profound know-how and skills.

Our consultants, sales engineers, supporters and partners work with our customers on a daily basis to implement, strengthen and fine-tune our solutions. They need to find the best options how to install third party software on top of our operating system, or to get the most out of our customers' infrastructure. Many proofs of concept and customer projects have been conducted. And many of them are at least partly documented. Also, many Technical Information Documents (TIDs) are already written and published on the webpage or in the Support Knowledgebase at , but it might be hard to find documents related to a specific topic.

Our own infrastructure department has to solve challenges, or already detected easy ways to implement a scenario which might occur similarly or might be helpul in a customer setup. One of our engineers may have detected a certain solution, which is not yet documented, to address a common problem in a repeatable manner.

This kind of information is usually buried on a personal laptop or a team server. Most of the existing documents are not in a shape that they can be published as are, because they refer to customers that we are not allowed to name or include some information that needs to be removed before publishing.
In short, a huge part of the knowledge that exists in our company is not publicly available for our colleagues, partners or customers. And if publicly available in any form, it often is hard to find.

sect2.title: Mission
sect2.para: The purpose of the &sbp; is to change this situation. We want to make existing knowledge and experience available to a broader audience, and we want to promote it via a recognizable series of documents.

sect2.title: Vision
sect2.para: With the &sbp;, we aim to introduce a new series of documents that provides reliable technical information. We want to establish a new go-to source for the usage and implementation of SUSE products and solutions, also in combination with third party software and hardware.

Our goal is to make the &sbp; series similarly prominent to the widely recognized IBM Redbooks which can be found at . We want volunteers knocking at our door to contribute and feeling honored if we pick their proposed topics for the &sbp;.

sect2.title: What Exactly Are the &sbp;?
sect2.para: In contrast to the SUSE product documentation which mainly guides through SUSE software installation and usage, the &sbp; are a series of topic-driven documentation and provide installation and implementation experiences.

A &sbp; document describes a technical scenario or solution that is not covered by the general comprehensive SUSE product documentation. Such a scenario can also include third-party software and implementations (partly) done by partners.

While our SUSE product documentation is delivered in parallel with a new product version, the &sbp; will not focus on newly launched products, but on products already introduced to and established in the market.
Usually the scenario or solution has already been implemented in a real-life scenario at a customer's site. It can include â€“ but is not limited to:

listitem.para: a specific, non-prevalent but repeatable setup
the installation of third-party software on top of a SUSE product
the implementation of a solution consisting of several products
a step-by-step procedure
a newly tested procedure
a proven process or methodology

sect2.para: &sbp; should be replicable and adaptable, they aim to save time as they use existing knowledge for further replication, and they should be sustainable and easy to update.

sect2.title: Target Audience
sect2.para: &sbp; target existing customers that work on a specific solution or must solve a concrete technical problem. We mainly address system administrators that have to set-up and implement the technical solution. &sbp; can also be of interest to technical architects as well as to technical support staff or helpdesk staff.

sect2.title: Advantages of &sbp;
sect2.para: FIXME
Our customers get access to additional information ...

We also want to ensure, that our colleagues who work on implementations at customer sites do not have to reinvent the wheel, but can save time and effort by capitalizing from existing documentation of similar setups.
Our sales colleagues benefit from &sbp; by being able to respond to many more customer requests much quicker.

sect1.title: Definition of Whitepapers, Success Stories, Case Studies, Blogs
sect1.para: In addition to the product documentation, SUSE provides written material to customers which is perceived by our customers as part of the SUSE documentation, but is created under responsibility of the Marketing teams. To avoid any confusion between the purpose of the &sbp; and Marketing material such as whitepapers, success stories, case studies, and blog entries, the next few paragraphs focus on the definition of these Marketing documents.

The target audience for the Marketing documents are mainly technical or business decision makers. They mostly target potential customers that do not yet run SUSE products, or customers to whom we want to upsell additional SUSE products. Marketing documents are mainly used for Demand Generation. In Marketing language, Demand Generation means: creating interest in our products and services, and building and nurturing key prospect and customer relationships for the long term.

You can find two different kinds of whitepapers at SUSE. Technical whitepapers provide a technical overview and are mainly product focused. They contain high level technical information, for example important technical features or technologies are explained and translated into their business benefits. These papers are written by Product Marketing. If required, the documentation team supports these whitepapers with proofreading or editing. Business whitepapers provide a business overview of a product or solution and focus mainly on the business value. Business whitepapers are completely done by the Marketing teams.

A Success Story must include the customer name within the story. It is approximately two pages in length and explains how a customer successfully implemented our products. It contains high level details of a customer project, direct quotes from the customer, and paints a short picture of the project â€“ from start to finish. It covers the problem, solution and results from a business perspective, and reveals why our customer chose our product(s) for the project.

A Case Study provides more details and specifics than a success story. In addition to the above, it showcases the how in the meaning of how a solution was delivered or how the solution works in the customerâ€™s environment. Case studies deliver much more in-depth technical information versus a success story. At SUSE, case studies are a minimum of four pages, and they must involve tangible measurements of results, such as cost savings or increases of efficiency. Their main purpose is to describe how a customer did benefit from the implementation of a SUSE product or solution by translating the technical information into measurable business results.

SUSE also provides a platform for a Corporate Blog at . A Corporate blog is published and used by an organization as one channel to reach its organizational goals. Corporate blogging serves multiple potential marketing goals, from driving awareness, to providing specific information, to building up relationship. The advantage of corporate blogs is that posts and comments are easy to reach and follow due to centralized hosting and generally structured conversation threads. On a corporate blog, employees, teams, or spokespersons share their personal views on certain topics. These topics can be from technical or from business nature. The corporate blog is often used to announce new products, to explain and clarify policies, or to react on certain issues. It also allows a window to the company culture and is often treated more informally than traditional press releases, though a corporate blog often tries to accomplish similar goals as press releases do.

sect1.title: Prerequisites for &sbp;
sect1.para: The main purpose of &sbp; is to make knowledge that already exists in written form in different departments of our company easily accessible for a broader internal and external audience. We can achieve this with the help of the documentation team via streamlined approaches and standardized processes.
This means also that the main content for a &sbp; paper is not delivered by the SUSE documentation team, but has to come from:

listitem.para: Consulting
Presales Engineers
Support
Partners
and on limited occasions also from Engineering

sect1.para: One reason why the SUSE documentation team cannot deliver the content is that we cannot reproduce the scenarios and environments implemented at our customers` sites. We heavily rely on the know-how and operating experience of our colleagues that are working directly with our partners or customers.

A minimum of 80 percent of a proposed or requested topic already needs to be available in written form. Before starting a new project, subject matter experts who worked together with a partner or customer on the implementation of the topic need to be defined, and they need to be committed to work on the paper together with the documentation team. All &sbp; are written in English only.

sect2.title: Contribution of Partners and Customers
sect2.para: Partners and customers can also request &sbp;, and participate in the creation of a document. The requirements are the same as for internal requesters.

sect2.title: openSUSE
sect2.para: We also accept requests for &sbp; for openSUSE. However, a topic requested for openSUSE must not conflict with any topic related to SUSE Linux Enterprise products.

sect2.title: Selection of Topics
sect2.para: The SUSE documentation team maintains a list of proposed topics on a Trello board and decides about the relevance and priority of all requests. Customer-relevant topics have higher priority.

sect1.title: How Does the SUSE Documentation Team Support
sect1.para: The SUSE documentation team is coordinating all requests for topics and updates. Whatâ€™s more, the team:

listitem.para: helps with finalizing the content where needed via face-to-face and phone interviews and e-mail conversations
corrects wording and fine-tuning of the content where needed
anonymizes the content anonymous, means it removes any reference to a specific customer
ports the content into the formal layout of SUSE documents and rewrites the content in DocBook XML
edits the content
coordinates proofreading
publishes the final paper on a public SUSE Web site or portal
promotes the paper via several channels

sect1.para: For writing the actual documents, the SUSE documentation team uses the official

listitem.para: The documentation team writes all content to be published in DocBook XML. It is based on the eXtensible Markup Language (XML) and defines the content in a semantic way through elements. This makes changes and updates easier. In addition, the &sbp; use a similar look-and-feel as the SUSE product documentation.

DAPS is a command-line tool the SUSE documentation team uses to generate output formats from the XML sources. &sbp; will be provided as single HTML (this means you can read the document from one HTML screen), PDF and ePub. DAPS also allows implementing a modular structure for a collection of papers related to a specific topic. It allows to run some other tasks related to writing and editing, such as a spell checker and the SUSE documentation style checker.

Git is the main version control system for the SUSE product documentation. GitHub is used as a hosting server for the sources. For the &sbp;, we also use GitHub to host the sources, to enable for collaboration with contributors spread over different locations. Initially, we will work with public repositories (see also ).

sect1.title: What the Documentation Team Does NOT Do for &sbp;
sect1.para: To re-emphasize, the SUSE Documentation team is not delivering or writing the general content for &sbp;. The documentation team will not test any described scenario or implementation, or validate the provided content, as it can not reproduce the scenarios.
For the same reasons, the documentation team is not responsible for delivering the content for updates of a SUSE Best Practices document.

&sbp; are provided in English only. The documentation team will not handle translations in any other language. If a SUSE department needs a translated version of a &sbp; document, the requesting department has to pay for the translation services. The SUSE documentation team can make up the contact to our translation services.

sect1.title: Layout and Style
sect1.para: The layout and style of &sbp; should lean on the official style guidelines and existing stylesheets. Our language and structure specifications are listed in the Style Guide. The guide provides answers to writing, style, and layout questions commonly arising when editing SUSE documentation. Keeping a certain standard and following our style specifications makes our documentation more understandable and easier to translate. However, the &sbp; do not necessarily need to fulfill the guidelines by 100 percent and provide for more flexibility regarding their language.
The &sbp; layout differs from a usual article and will be structured as follows:

listitem.para: Title page, contains:
Name of the series, &sbp;
Title
Subtitle
Names of products involved in the solution or set up
Author(s) details (full name, title, company)
Date of publication
SUSE logo
Partner company logo(s) (if needed)
Second page, contains:
Abstract
Table of content
Content body
License information

sect1.para: The language style of a &sbp; adheres to the SUSE style guide. Use a clear and concise sentence structure. Avoid abbreviations and contractions. Use direct speech for &sbp; because they address the user, but avoid first person perspective. However, keep in mind that the style of a &sbp; can be take a more narrative form than a documentation article or book.
The &sbp; can include more graphical elements than a manual might contain. To ensure that all graphical elements can be displayed well in all different output formats, the following rules apply:

listitem.para: Provide screenshots in PNG format.
Provide charts, graphics and other drawings in SVG format.
Provide images and pictures as high resolution JPEG or TIFF files.
Do not provide computer output as screenshots, but write them down as text. This makes updates or changes easier.

sect1.title: Updates
sect1.para: The content for updates of &sbp; has to come from the original content provider, or from another subject matter expert familiar with the topic, defined in advance.

Based on the availability of information for the topic, the documentation team decides if a &sbp; will be updated or not. Also, the documentation team decides about removing a published paper from the official portal when the information seems to be outdated, and no subject matter expert volunteers to update the existing content.

sect1.title: License
sect1.para: SUSE documentation is usually published under an open document license, such as the GNU Free Documentation License , or the Creative Commons .

This is also the case for &sbp;. We reserve the right to change the copyright of a &sbp; document to a proprietary license in cases where a key contributor has valid reasons to require this or where we see the exigency to do so to protect SUSE`s business. In the latter case, the paper will be published under SUSE copyright.

sect1.title: Recognition of Authors
sect1.para: SUSE does not pay authors or contributors for the delivery of content for a &sbp; document. Nevertheless we want to recognize the efforts for the contribution to &sbp; by several means:

listitem.para: The key content providers for a &sbp; document will be highlighted as authors of the document. Their full name, job title, and company will be publicized.
If a &sbp; document is written in co-authorship with another company, the logo of the partner company is be printed on the title page, in addition to the SUSE logo.
Key contributors to &sbp; will receive a limited edition SUSE or openSUSE branded business gift.

sect1.para: In addition to the above, we provide incentives for collaboration on &sbp;. Key contributors to &sbp; will receive a (limited) edition SUSE or openSUSE branded business gift. These items can be but are not limited to:

listitem.para: SUSE logo as plush animal
Special edition of T-Shirts
Technical gadgets

sect1.para: In a first step, we will give away a SUSE Logo plush animal (Geeko) of one meter of size.

sect2.title: Convincing the Teams that Have to Deliver the Content
sect2.para: As most of the content for &sbp; needs to come from teams outside the enginnering departments, such as Consulting, Support, Alliances or Sales, we must get the buy-in from the respective directors and team leads.

Most of them in direct conversations already agreed that content as planned to be provided with the &sbp; is needed and required by customers. However, the challenge is to transform the consense into a commitment.
This commitment has to be twofold:

listitem.para: The directors and team leads need to understand that for the &sbp; we need to work with documentation that in big parts has been created for projects or proof of concepts for a specific customer. Typically we are not allowed to use project-specific material for public purposes. If we ask customers directly to allow us to use the material, many of them will object to it.

One way to circumvent this hurdle is to include an official clause with our consulting and sales contracts, which declares that project or customer documentation can be reused in an anonymized manner for SUSE documentation purposes.

The managers of the Consulting, Support, Alliances and Presales teams need to free up some time of their team members for the work on &sbp;. They need to understand that they cannot charge the documentation team for the time worked on &sbp;.

sect2.para: We will only get the commitment if we succeed to make the stakeholders in Consulting, Support, Alliances and Sales understand that the &sbp; represent a win-win situation. They will not hurt their customers, but benefit existing as well as potential new customers. In addition, they help our colleagues from these departments to save time as they do not have to reinvent the wheel for many projects because they can rely on accessible documentation.

The question is now how to approach the stakeholders from these departments? Should we approach them bottom-up or top-down? Do we talk to them ourselves in a first step, or do we ask our SUSE Senior Leadership team to approach them? If we decide for the bottom-up approach, can we secure backing from the Senior Leadership Team to put some pressure on them?

sect2.title: Communication and Promotion of &sbp;
sect2.para: First of all, we need to get official approval for the &sbp; from the ELT. A presentation about the &sbp; must be created for this purpose. We already have buy-in from our CTO Thomas Di Giacomo.
To communicate the &sbp; internally and promote them externally, we need to work with the Marketing departments.

Before we can make anything public, we should have a conversation with Jo Harris and her directors, and get their buy-in, too. Mainly Product Marketing provides high level technical whitepapers. We need to make Marketing understand that we do not compete with them by providing additonal whitepapers, but that we deliver additional material which they can also use for Marketing purposes and which nobody provided so far via streamlined processes.
After that conversation took place, we should cooperate with Marketing to communicate the &sbp; to our colleagues. There are several channels:

listitem.para: Every 1st Tuesday of a month, the SUSE Marketing department has an extended Marketing meeting via phone. We can ask to be invited to that meeting to introduce the &sbp; to the Marketing groups.

Marketing provides a monthly newsletter for customer- and partner facing departments inside SUSE, with relevant information and links. We can ask them to include the information about the &sbp; to that newsletter.

Internal SUSE-wide newsbriefs are distributed via email to all employees. They are created and distributed under responsibility of MarCom. To send out a SUSE-wide newsbrief, we need to get approval from Jo Harris. Scott Corfield can help us to set up the newsbrief.

To reach especially all our Sales teams, we can work with Rich Wiltbank from Sales Enablement on an announcement or a Field Memo via the Sales Enablement mailinglis, or a presentation slot within the series of Sales Enablement webinars.
To get our partners on board, we need to work with the Alliances teams to get a slot on their regular update calls.

sect2.para: After the internal communication took place, we need to promote the &sbp; to the public. Again, we need to use multiple channels to push awareness for the &sbp;:

listitem.para: Social media channels, including Twitter, SUSE communities and blogs, Facebook, LinkedIn, Google+,
Official SUSE Press Release or News Item, via our PR managers Kevan Barney and Vera Schneider. Rob Ahern is the Director for PR and MarCom and should be involved early.
Marketing sends out a monthly newsletter to the entire SUSE customer database. Scott Corfield is responsible for the external newsletter. We can request to get an article in one of the next items.

sect2.title: Budget
sect2.para: We do not pay for content contribution, but we have got feedback from the field that as a stimulus, the key authors and contributors for an SBP should receive a special or limited SUSE Merchandise item. In a first step, we have ordered huge plush SUSE Geekos.

But we need to decide and define as soon as possible how to proceed after we ran out of stock. Also, if an author contributes to more than one paper, we should provide a different item as recognition. Thus we should be prepared for additional incentives.

listitem.para: The idea is to create individual T-Shirts, produced on a per needbasis.
The cost is roughly 25 Euro per item.
In addition, we can work with Field Marketing to order smaller numbers of different technical gadgets (bluetooth speakers, power banks, or similar).
We should plan with roughly 1,000 Euro for additional incentives.

sect2.para: There is a budget for the translation of documentation, but this budget is calculated only for proofreading and translating the proper product documentation SUSE Best Practices will be published in English, translations are not planned. However, to ensure the quality of the SBPâ€™s regarding proper language, we need to make sure that we will have a budget available for proofreading.
From our translation service provider, we got a quote for proofreading:

listitem.para: Proofreading costs us 70 Euro per 20 pages.
Minimum order value is 70 Euro per 20 pages.
We can accumulate shorter papers to match the minimum order of 20 pages.
For FY17, we estimate we will to work on 20 &sbp; documents with an average length of 20 pages.
This means we need a budget of roughly Euro 1,500 for proofreading.

sect2.title: Collaboration Platforms
sect2.para: Collaboration space for topic list: Currently we maintain the general list for topics on Trello. This list is an internal one. Is this the right place to make sure all stakeholders and decision makers for &sbp; have access? Which other tools exist that might be suitable?

Collaboration space for writers/subject matter experts: We need to define which platform we use for collaboration with our contributors, no matter if internal or external. Currently, our repository for &sbp; is a public repositors on GitHub. Do we need to provide a private space, too? Or should we decide about this topic when the request for a private collaboration space comes up.

sect2.title: &sbp; Portal
sect2.para: For the &sbp;, we plan to implement a specific portal built for this new series of documents. We still need to discuss the requirements and parameters of the portal.
